videoTitle: DevOps Topologies 10 years on: What have we learned about silos, collaboration, and flow?
videoDescription:
Keynote at The DEVOPS Conference Global - London, on March 2024: DevOps Topologies 10 years on: What have we learned about silos, collaboration, and flow?

----
 
In this talk, Matthew Skelton explores the key learnings from 10 years of Team Topologies and State of DevOps Reports and outlines key steps that organizations can take to improve IT delivery performance:

- Organize for flow
- Address team cognitive load
- Estimate the cost of “tangled software”
- Use the Accelerate metrics and community techniques to find good boundaries for flow 
- Develop secure foundations in social and technical practices that support fast flow
- Take a realistic view about the nature and scale of change needed

By combining learnings from State of DevOps Reports and Team Topologies together with principles championed by the DevOps community, organizations can navigate a route to business agility via a fast flow operating model.

----

Speaker: Matthew Skelton, Co-author of Team Topologies, and CEO at Conflux

Matthew Skelton is co-author of the award-winning and ground-breaking book Team Topologies, and Founder & Principal at Conflux. The Team Topologies book was rated one of the ‘Best product management books of all time’ by Book Authority and is widely used by organizations worldwide to transform the way they deliver value.

Matthew is one of the foremost leaders in modern organizational dynamics for fast flow, drawing on Team Topologies and related practices to support organizations with transformation towards a sustainable fast flow of value and true business agility. 

A Chartered Engineer (CEng), Matthew brings together principles and practices from multiple disciplines for a holistic approach to digitally-enriched operating models. He combines his experience as a leader and software architect in multiple contexts (GOV.UK, ecommerce, financial services, telecoms, pharma, retail, robotics, etc.) with a strong interest in the human side of organizations for a compassionate and humanistic approach to organizational effectiveness. #DevOps #thedevopsconference

videoTitle: 📈🎓Mastering the DevOps Engineer Road Map🌟🔧 | #thillaithetechie
videoDescription:
✅ Foundational Knowledge: Understand Linux, scripting (Python/Bash), and networking basics.

✅ Version Control: Master Git for source code management and collaboration.

✅ CI/CD Pipelines: Learn Jenkins, Travis CI, or CircleCI to automate testing and deployments.

✅ Configuration Management: Gain expertise in Ansible, Puppet, or Chef for infrastructure as code.

✅ Containers and Orchestration: Dive into Docker and Kubernetes for efficient application deployment.

✅ Cloud Platforms: Get hands-on experience with AWS, Azure, or Google Cloud for scalable solutions.

✅ Monitoring and Logging: Implement tools like Prometheus, Grafana, and ELK stack for system monitoring.

videoTitle: Create Managed Azure DevOps Pools with Terraform
videoDescription:
Today we're working with Azure Pipelines and exploring the different options you have when working with agent pools. The main focus will be on the new Azure Managed DevOps Agent Pools, what they are, how they work, and why you might want to use them.

We’ll start by deploying some prerequisites using Terraform, including a virtual network to host our agents. You’ll see how to use the AzAPI provider to get the job done and I’ll walk you through it all, step by step, as we build this Terraform project from scratch.

Once everything is up and running, we’ll connect our agent to an Azure Pipeline and run a deployment to test it out.

If you’re looking to automate Azure DevOps agent pool provisioning with Terraform and AzAPI, or just want to learn more about CI/CD in Azure, you’re in the right place. Hope you enjoy the video!

Timestamps: 
0:00 Intro
1:00 Differences between managed devops pools and other offerings

33:30 Deploying our code
34:10 Create pipelines and test our pool
38:20 Recap and outro

☁️ About ZopDev ☁️

Welcome to the official ZopDev YouTube channel! ZopDev is the Pre-Engineered Cloud Platform designed to revolutionize how you deploy and manage cloud infrastructure.

Tired of complex setups and endless configuration? We deploy a battle-tested, secure, and compliant infrastructure foundation directly into your AWS, Azure, or GCP account in under 30 minutes.

Think of ZopDev as the "coworking space of cloud infra": everything essential (networking, security, observability, CI/CD foundations) is expertly set up, optimized, and ready to go. videoTitle: Azure DevOps GitHub Integration with 2-way Sync and Real-Time Updates
videoDescription:
Here's how to quickly set up a secure, seamless 2-way integration that keeps your development teams in sync between Azure DevOps and GitHub. 

00:00 - Use Case
00:30 - Sync Demo
01:30 - Connect to Unito
02:00 - Flow Direction
02:25 - Set Rules and Triggers
02:51 - Linking Fields and Configurations

✨Try it free today:✨
🔗 https://bit.ly/3tAQXYN

Unito supports essential fields in Azure DevOps and GitHub, including:

💼 Title: The title or summary of the issue or work item provides a brief description of what the task or issue entails.

📝 Description: The detailed description of the issue or work item, including any additional information or context needed for team members to understand the task.

👤 Assignee: The person responsible for completing the task or addressing the issue. Keeping the assignee field in sync ensures that the correct team member is aware of their responsibilities.

🔢 Status: The current status of the issue or work item, such as "To Do," "In Progress," or "Done." Syncing the status field helps everyone stay updated on the progress of tasks.

🔝 Priority: The priority level of the issue or work item, which helps determine its importance and urgency. Syncing the priority field ensures that team members are aligned on task prioritization.

📌 Work Item Type/Issue Type: The type of work item or issue, such as bug, feature, or task. Syncing this field provides clarity and consistency in categorizing different types of work.

🏷️ Labels/Tags: Categorizing issues or work items with labels or tags helps with organization and filtering. Keeping these fields in sync ensures consistent labeling across both platforms.

💬 Comments/Updates: Any comments or updates made on an issue or work item should be synced to provide real-time collaboration and visibility for everyone involved.

⏰ Due Date: If there is a specific deadline or due date associated with the task or issue, syncing this field helps the team stay on track and meet deadlines.

📎 Attachments: Any files or attachments related to the issue or work item should be synced to ensure easy access and collaboration.

------------

videoTitle: Understanding the DevOps Threat Matrix | Defender for Cloud in the Field #34
videoDescription:
In this episode of Defender for Cloud in the Field, Ariel Brukman joins Yuri Diogenes to talk about the DevOps Threat Matrix. Ariel talks about the process of creating a new threat matrix for a very complex domain such as DevOps, what it was found during the research process and how the research evolved to create this threat matrix. Ariel also talks about how to use the threat matrix to improve your DevOps defenses, and he gives examples of some common attacks against DevOps environments. 

02:49 - The research leading to DevOps Matrix publication

08:50 - Privilege escalation phase
13:00 - Common patterns of attack
13:42 - Recommendations to build better defenses

Manage & Secure Kubernetes Cluster Policies via OPA Gatekeeper. #opa #devops #gatekeepers 

Timestamps:

Theory/Concepts : 00:00
Hands on/Practical : 09:00

github repo : https://github.com/RohanRusta21/opa-gatekeeper.git

Concepts :

OPA Gatekeeper: Policy and Governance for Kubernetes

What is OPA:

The Open Policy Agent (OPA) is an open-source, general-purpose policy engine that unifies policy enforcement across the stack. OPA provides a high-level declarative language that lets us specify policies as code and simple APIs to offload policy decision-making from our software. We can use OPA to enforce policies in microservices, Kubernetes, CI/CD pipelines, API gateways, and more. 
In kubernetes, OPA uses admission controllers.

What is OPA Gatekeeper?

OPA Gatekeeper is a specialized project providing first-class integration between OPA and Kubernetes.
OPA Gatekeeper adds the following on top of plain OPA:
● An extensible, parameterized policy library.
● Native Kubernetes CRDs for instantiating the policy library (aka “constraints”).
● Native Kubernetes CRDs for extending the policy library (aka “constraint templates”).
● Audit functionality.

Why you need Gatekeeper?

As a Platform DevOps engineer managing multiple Kubernetes clusters for various projects, you face challenges when users deploy applications without adhering to best practices. Key issues include:
  1.     Lack of ownership unless users apply labels themselves.
  2.     No resource limits, leading to high costs.
  3.     Untrusted images impacting other applications.
  4.     Security and best practice violations across clusters.

To address these, we need governance to enforce limits and rules via policies. OPA Gatekeeper can be configured to implement these policies, ensuring best practices are followed.

videoTitle: Cracking the DevOps Code: Courses & Certifications for Success
videoDescription:
Take the courses mentioned here, get certifications and do not forget to add these using our AI-Powered Resume Builder (https://pro.kudoswall.com)
Certifications for Employed DevOps Professionals:
AWS Certified DevOps Engineer: This certification from Amazon Web Services (AWS) validates your expertise in deploying, operating, and managing applications on the AWS platform.
Azure DevOps Engineer: Offered by Microsoft, this certification demonstrates your skills in designing and implementing DevOps practices using Azure technologies.
Google Cloud Professional DevOps Engineer: This certification focuses on designing, developing, and managing DevOps practices on the Google Cloud Platform.
Certified Kubernetes Administrator (CKA): Certified by the Cloud Native Computing Foundation (CNCF), CKA validates your Kubernetes skills, which are crucial for container orchestration.
Certified Jenkins Engineer: Offered by CloudBees, this certification recognizes your proficiency in using Jenkins for continuous integration and continuous delivery (CI/CD) pipelines.
Red Hat Certified Engineer in DevOps: This certification from Red Hat validates your skills in using Red Hat technologies for automating, managing, and optimizing DevOps processes.

Courses for Aspiring DevOps Engineers:
Introduction to DevOps Practices: Online platforms like Coursera, edX, and Udemy offer various introductory courses that cover the fundamental concepts and practices of DevOps.
Docker and Kubernetes Courses: Understanding containerization and orchestration tools like Docker and Kubernetes is essential. There are numerous courses available for beginners and advanced users.
Cloud Platform Courses (AWS, Azure, GCP): Learning the basics of cloud platforms and their DevOps-related services is crucial. Many platforms offer free and paid courses for beginners.
CI/CD Pipeline Courses: Courses on continuous integration and continuous delivery tools like Jenkins, GitLab CI/CD, and CircleCI are essential for automating software delivery.
Infrastructure as Code (IaC) Courses: Learning tools like Terraform and Ansible for automating infrastructure deployment is key for DevOps engineers.
Monitoring and Logging Courses: Understanding tools like Prometheus, Grafana, and ELK Stack (Elasticsearch, Logstash, Kibana) for monitoring and logging is vital.
Scripting and Programming Courses: Proficiency in scripting languages like Python and programming languages like Java can enhance your DevOps skills.
Security and Compliance Courses: DevOps engineers should also be well-versed in security practices. Courses on DevSecOps and security automation can be beneficial.
#DevOpsIndia #Certifications #Courses #TechSkills #CareerGrowth #Cloud #Automation

videoTitle: D365 F&O: Setup an Azure DevOps CI Build Pipeline | Part 7
videoDescription:
Set up a CI pipeline for D365 in Azure DevOps. Learn to deploy a Build VM and automate your code builds for team development.

───────────
🕒 Timestamps
───────────

0:00 → Intro: Why We Need a CI Pipeline (Continuous Integration)
0:25 → Part 1: Create a Self-Hosted Agent Pool in ADO
1:19 → Part 2: Provision the Build VM in LCS
1:54 → Selecting the "Build and Test" Topology
2:24 → Advanced Settings: Linking the ADO Agent Pool & Branch
3:04 → Selecting the VM Size (Memory Optimized)
3:47 → Part 3: Configure the Build VM (Reset Password & Connect)
4:24 → Exploring the Build VM File Structure (SDK Folder)
4:53 → Part 4: Review the Auto-Generated Build Pipeline
5:43 → Enabling Continuous Integration Triggers & Path Filters
6:23 → Part 5: Branching Strategy (Rename 'dev' to 'Main')
6:52 → Connecting Visual Studio to Source Control (Team Explorer)
7:19 → Mapping a Local Workspace
7:55 → Adding the Local Project to Source Control
8:34 → Adding the axmodulesbuild File & Checking In
9:12 → Part 6: Creating a New 'dev' Branch from 'Main'
10:06 → Part 7: How the CI Build Process Works
10:23 → Reviewing the Build Stages (Build, Sync, Package)
10:59 → Under the Hood: Pipeline Tasks vs. VM Scripts
11:53 → Part 8: Reviewing the Final Build Artifact
12:27 → Recap

──────────────
💡 What You'll Learn
──────────────

✓ Create a self-hosted Agent Pool in Azure DevOps for D365 builds.
✓ How to deploy a Build VM from LCS and connect it to your pipeline.
✓ Configure an auto-generated build pipeline with CI triggers and path filters.
✓ Connect Visual Studio to Azure DevOps (TFVC) using Team Explorer.
✓ Check in your code to automatically trigger the build and create a Deployable Package.

──────────────────────────
🚀 About This D365 Development Series
──────────────────────────

This series goes beyond basic tutorials to show you how real-world Dynamics 365 (D365FO) projects are built from start to finish. We'll build a complete, end-to-end "Automated Customer Tiering System" for a fictional client, Bluestone Industrial Components (BIC).

You'll see every step of a production-ready solution, from setup to deployment, covering:
➤ Core X++ Development: Extending tables and forms (CustTable), creating Enums, and implementing custom business logic using Chain of Command (CoC).
➤ Automation: Building robust, automated batch jobs with the SysOperation Framework.
➤ APIs & Integration: Creating Data Entities to build secure OData REST APIs and for Data Management Framework (DMF) exports.
➤ Event-Driven Architecture: Firing real-time alerts from D365 to Azure Logic Apps using Business Events.
➤ Business Intelligence: Connecting D365 to Power BI to build an interactive sales dashboard.
➤ DevOps & ALM: Setting up a complete CI/CD pipeline in Azure DevOps, managing source control (TFVC), and automating builds.

────────────────
💻 Tools & Technologies
────────────────

🔹Dynamics 365 Finance & Operations (D365FO)
🔹X++
🔹Visual Studio 2019
🔹Lifecycle Services (LCS)
🔹Azure DevOps (ADO)
🔹SQL Server Management Studio (SSMS)
🔹Power BI Desktop
🔹Azure Logic Apps

───────────────────
💬 Feedback & Future Topics
───────────────────

This series covers the core components of a practical, end-to-end D365 project. I know there are many more topics we could dive into, from advanced debugging to complex form patterns.

I welcome your feedback and ideas! If there's a specific D365 topic you'd like to see covered in a future video, please share your suggestions in the comments section below.

#Dynamics365, #AzureDevOps, #ContinuousIntegration, #D365Development

videoTitle: How We Fixed a 502 Bad Gateway in Production | Real DevOps Incident (Day 7)
videoDescription:
🚨 Day 7 of the DevOps in ARIA – Real-Time Scenario Series

Scenario:
Production just went down with a 502 Bad Gateway after a critical deployment. Jenkins pipeline triggered it, the deployment failed — and users were impacted.

🎯 Here’s how we handled it in real time:

Checked logs — the app was failing health checks

Root cause: a missing production environment variable

Rolled back the deployment safely using Helm

Fixed the configuration and stopped further rollouts

Patched the CI/CD pipeline to catch such issues early

🎥 Watch this short video to learn how real DevOps teams fix issues fast under pressure — and how you can too.

Takeaway:
Handling incidents is not just about tools — it’s about staying calm, investigating smartly, and improving your pipeline for the future.

💬 Have you faced a 502 in production? How did you resolve it? Let’s share and learn from each other in the comments.

videoTitle: What is Git? How would you define Git? || #GitHub #GitLab #BitBucket #DevOps #Git #Python #Java
videoDescription:
What is Git?

How would you define Git?

Well, Git is a distributed version control system, which means two things:

1. It's distributed so people around the world can share code
2. It does version control

So, with version control, you can take snapshots of the state of your current code and maintain a history.

Branching is really the third thing. Git branches allow developers to do isolated development and take chances without messing up the main branch.

So when someone asks me 'What is Git?', that is how I typically respond.

videoTitle: SBOM & Security Scanning in CI/CD | Secure Your DevOps Pipeline with GitHub Actions
videoDescription:
🚀 SBOM & Security Scanning in CI/CD | Secure Your DevOps Pipeline with GitHub Actions 🔒

In this video, we take CI/CD security to the next level by integrating SBOM (Software Bill of Materials) generation and advanced security scanning into your GitHub Actions workflow. If you're only scanning container images for vulnerabilities, you're missing hidden risks! 😱

We’ll cover:
✅ What is SBOM & Why You Need It? 📜
✅ How to Generate an SBOM with Syft 🔍
✅ Scanning Dependencies for Vulnerabilities with Grype 🚨
✅ Performing Full Security Scans with Trivy 🛡
✅ Step-by-Step CI/CD Implementation using GitHub Actions

By the end of this video, you'll have an automated security pipeline that ensures complete supply chain security in your CI/CD workflows! 🔥

🔄 Hands-on Demo:
We'll walk through a real-world GitHub Actions pipeline that:
🔹 Generates an SBOM with Syft
🔹 Scans dependencies with Grype
🔹 Conducts a deep security scan on container images with Trivy
🔹 Automates security checks in every code push & pull request

🖥️ Watch as we push a change to GitHub and trigger an automated security scan in real-time!

🔹 What’s Next?
In our next video, we’ll bring everything together into a complete DevSecOps pipeline using GitHub Actions! 🚀

I am gonna tell you what DevOps engineers do in less than a minute with an example.

In a restaurant kitchen, there are chefs and wait staff.

Chefs are responsible for creating and experimenting with new dishes. Their job includes coming up with innovative recipes, testing them, and adding the successful ones to the menu. At the same time, they also prepare food to meet the regular demand of customers who visit the restaurant daily. This dual responsibility of innovation and ongoing service can become overwhelming, especially during busy hours when the kitchen is already at full capacity.

Wait staff, on the other hand, focus on delivering the prepared food to customers. Their primary role is to ensure that the food reaches the diners promptly and in perfect condition, keeping the restaurant’s operations running smoothly.

Experimenting with a new dish during peak hours, however, becomes a significant challenge. The process of testing new recipes while maintaining the flow of regular orders often leads to disruptions in the kitchen, causing delays and dissatisfaction among customers.

To address this, the restaurant hires a kitchen manager. The kitchen manager creates a separate small kitchen dedicated to experimenting with new dishes. This ensures that the chefs can focus on their innovations without interfering with the ongoing operations. Once a dish is perfected, the kitchen manager introduces automation, such as using a conveyor belt, to streamline the cooking process. This allows the new dish to be produced efficiently alongside the existing menu items while ensuring there are no interruptions in serving food to the restaurant's customers.

Yes, DevOps engineers are none other than automation experts.

videoTitle: What's the goal of Platform Engineering? #shorts #devops #platformengineering
videoDescription:
Watch the full video: https://youtu.be/JAblex0uS4k

What’s the goal of Platform Engineering? Platform Engineering focusses on the building the infrastructure and the systems that are needed for running your applications and supporting your application throughout the software life cycle. So,  the goal  is to support the developers in the organisation and treat them as customers. That’s why we have in platform engineering the concept of IDP Internal developer platform.
 
So, this platform is treated as an actual product and the customers of the product are the developers.
What is the role of the IDP?
It is to create a thin layer on top of the toolchain that is used inside the organisation to standardise the processes and help developers to have one way to deploy into production

videoTitle: RabbitMQ for DevOps Engineers: Hands-On Demo for Beginners #devops #rabbitmq  #kubernetes
videoDescription:
RabbitMQ for DevOps Engineers: Hands-On Demo for Beginners #devops #rabbitmq  #kubernetes

Github Repo : https://github.com/RohanRusta21/demo_rabbitmq.git

RabbitMQ Official Doc : https://www.rabbitmq.com/docs

Timestamp:
Understand Concept : 00:00
RabbitMQ Hands-on : 22:06

🧠 1. What Is RabbitMQ?

RabbitMQ is an open-source message broker — it acts as a middleman between different parts of a system that need to communicate asynchronously.
It uses the AMQP (Advanced Message Queuing Protocol) as its core protocol.

In simpler terms:

It receives messages from producers (applications sending data),

Stores them temporarily in queues,

And delivers them to consumers (applications receiving data).

This helps decouple systems — the sender and receiver don’t need to be active at the same time.

⚙️ 2. Why Use RabbitMQ?

✅ Decoupling – Producers don’t need to know who consumes messages.
✅ Asynchronous communication – Improves system responsiveness.
✅ Load balancing – Messages can be distributed across multiple consumers.
✅ Reliability – Ensures message delivery even if parts of the system fail.
✅ Scalability – You can add more queues or consumers easily.
✅ Flexible routing – Decide how messages flow using exchanges and routing keys.

🔩 3. Core RabbitMQ Concepts
🏭 Producers

Applications that send messages to RabbitMQ.
They don’t send messages directly to a queue but to an exchange.

🎯 Exchanges

An exchange routes messages to queues based on routing rules.

Exchange types:

Type Behavior Example Use Case
Direct Routes messages to queues whose binding key exactly matches routing key Task queues
Fanout Broadcasts all messages to all queues bound to it Notifications, pub/sub
Topic Routes messages based on pattern matching (* and #) Selective subscriptions
Headers Routes based on header attributes Advanced filtering

videoTitle: The "Hidden" Linux Memory Leak 🐧 #devops #linux #bash
videoDescription:
Stop blaming your application for every memory leak! 🛑

Sometimes the Linux Kernel is the one hoarding your RAM. In this video, we use slabtop to uncover "Invisible" memory consumption caused by Dentry and Inode caches.

Commands used in this video: 1️⃣ grep SUnreclaim /proc/meminfo — See if the Kernel is locking RAM. 2️⃣ sudo slabtop -o -s c — Find the specific metadata hog. 3️⃣ echo 2 | sudo tee /proc/sys/vm/drop_caches — Force a reclaim.

The Real Solution: Tuning vm.vfs_cache_pressure is the senior move to prevent this from happening in production.

🧠 Want to find leaks inside your ACTUAL code? Watch my deep dive on User-Space memory leaks here: [LINK TO YOUR LONG VIDEO]

videoTitle: Day 27 – ARM Templates & Bicep with Azure DevOps | 30 Days Azure DevOps Challenge
videoDescription:
🚀 Welcome to Day 27 of my 30 Days Azure DevOps Challenge!

🔹 Topic: ARM Templates & Bicep with Azure DevOps

Yesterday, we learned how Terraform brings Infrastructure as Code (IaC) to multiple clouds.
Today, we’re focusing on Azure-native IaC tools:

👉 Key differences:

ARM Templates → JSON files that define Azure resources.

Bicep → A cleaner, simpler language to write the same infrastructure.

✅ Why use them?

Strong native Azure support

Seamless integration with Azure DevOps

Best fit for teams working mainly within Azure

✨ Key takeaway:

Terraform = multi-cloud flexibility 🌎

ARM/Bicep = deep Azure integration & simplicity 💡

📌 Next in Day 28, I’ll cover Monitoring & Logging in Azure DevOps — making sure your apps and pipelines run reliably!

👉 Don’t forget to like 👍, share 🔁, and subscribe 🔔 for more daily DevOps learning!

videoTitle: Linux Commands That DevOps Engineers Use Every Single Day
videoDescription:
Welcome back to the Linux for DevOps Engineers playlist!

In this hands-on session, we focus on the essential Linux commands used daily by DevOps, SRE, Cloud, and Kubernetes engineers.

This is not a command memorisation tutorial; it's real, practical understanding.
Linux Essential Commands | Linux for DevOps Engineers
In this session, you will learn:

✅ How to know where you are in Linux (pwd, ls)
✅ How to navigate directories using cd (absolute + relative paths)
✅ How to create files & folders using mkdir, echo, cat
✅ How to find files with find
✅ How to search inside files using grep
✅ How to check system info, kernel version & disk health (uname, df -h, du -sh)
✅ How to monitor live logs using tail -f
✅ How to view system service logs using journalctl
✅ How to edit files with vi/vim without getting stuck
✅ A practice task to build confidence

This video is designed for complete beginners, DevOps learners, and anyone preparing for Linux + Kubernetes work.

videoTitle: Stop using Read-Host and do this instead #powershell  #devops  #scripting
videoDescription:
Stop using Read-Host and do this instead:

Read-Host has limitations. 

- You cannot pass information to it 
- You cannot validate what the user provided
- It always stops the script

There is a better way - use parameters instead.

- Control the type of input
- Make it mandatory or optional
- Pass argument from the command line
- or prompt the user to provide an argument, when required and not passed

In this short video, I'll show you how to implement simple parameters and how to use them.

Would you like to learn more about the parameters?

videoDescription:

videoTitle: 99% of DevOps Engineers Don’t Understand This Networking Flow (End-to-End Explained)
videoDescription:
Every time you type a website URL and press Enter, an invisible journey begins.

But…
👉 Do you really know what happens behind the scenes?
👉 How does your request travel from a browser to a Kubernetes pod?
👉 Why do failures happen even when “everything looks fine”?

In this video, we trace ONE single web request end-to-end and break down networking in a way that finally makes sense — without boring theory.

🔍 What You’ll Learn in This Video

✔ What DNS actually does (and why most outages start here)
✔ How HTTPS works and why TLS handshakes matter
✔ TCP/IP explained from a real debugging perspective
✔ Firewalls, ports, and security groups — simplified
✔ Load balancers and how they protect systems from failure
✔ Kubernetes networking: Ingress, Services, and Pods
✔ How to debug production issues layer by layer

This is not just networking theory — this is real-world DevOps networking, explained using stories, visuals, and practical insights.

👨‍💻 Who This Video Is For

DevOps Engineers

Cloud Engineers (AWS / GCP / Azure)

Kubernetes beginners & professionals

Backend developers

Anyone preparing for interviews or real production work

🧠 Why This Video Is Different

Most tutorials teach networking in silos.
This video teaches the entire journey of a request, the way production systems actually work.

“If you can understand one request deeply, you can debug any system.”

videoTitle: 90 Days DevOps Challenge | Day 42 | Advanced Terraform Concepts (Modules, Remote Backends)
videoDescription:
Welcome to Day 42 of the 90 Days DevOps Challenge!
Today, we dive deeper into Advanced Terraform Concepts that every DevOps engineer must know. Terraform is powerful, but to use it at scale in real projects, you need Modules and Remote Backends.
In this session, you will learn:
• What are Terraform Modules & why they matter
• Writing and using reusable Terraform Modules
• Using Terraform Registry for community modules
• Best practices for organizing modules in real projects
• Remote Backends for team collaboration
• Storing state securely in AWS S3 + DynamoDB
• When to use modules vs workspaces
By the end of this video, you’ll be able to build scalable, reusable, and production-grade infrastructure using Terraform Modules and manage your state safely with Remote Backends.

videoTitle: I Tried Learning DevOps Only From Documentation — Most People Would Quit
videoDescription:
Everyone tells you to watch tutorials to learn DevOps.

That’s not how I learned it.

In this video, I share my real DevOps learning method — exactly how I used to learn tools when I was starting out:
• Opening official documentation
• Following it step by step
• Breaking things
• Fixing real errors
• Learning how engineers actually think

This is a raw 1-hour session using Jenkins official documentation — no courses, no scripts, no shortcuts, no AI.

You’ll see:
• How beginners actually get stuck
• What documentation explains well (and what it doesn’t)
• Why pipelines fail even when you “follow the steps”
• How real DevOps engineers debug without answers

⚠️ This is NOT a polished tutorial
⚠️ This is NOT a crash course
✅ This is real DevOps learning in action

If you’re serious about learning DevOps, CI/CD, or Jenkins, this mindset matters more than tools.

videoTitle: Linux Package Management for DevOps: Stop Breaking Your Deployments
videoDescription:
Linux Package Management for DevOps: Stop Breaking Your Deployments

Package managers are not exciting. But if you’re a DevOps or Kubernetes engineer, they are absolutely foundational.

In this video, you’ll learn Linux package management the way it really matters in production as an ongoing operational responsibility, not a one-time setup task. We’ll connect tools like yum, apt and dnf directly to Ansible, CI/CD pipelines and Kubernetes nodes so you actually understand what you’re automating.

What you’ll learn:
00:00 - Why DevOps engineers must understand package managers
01:01 - Package Management in Real Cloud & Enterprise Environments
01:19 - How DevOps Engineers Actually Use Package Managers (Reality Check)
01:29 - What You’ll Learn in This Video (Scope & Expectations)
01:59 - What Is a Package Manager? (Concept, Not Commands)
02:47 - Where Yum Gets Packages From & What It Really Does
03:15 - RHEL Subscription Manager Explained (Enterprise Reality)
05:33 - When You Don’t Use Subscription Manager (Air-gapped & Internal Repos)
05:52 - Yum Repository Configuration Explained (/etc/yum.repos.d)
07:32 - Core Yum Commands DevOps Engineers Use Daily
11:15 - Production Updates: What NOT to Do & How Updates Really Work
12:14 - Why Blind yum update -y Breaks Production
12:52 - Package Managers Across Distros (Yum vs Apt vs Zypper)
13:37 - Final Takeaway: Why This Layer Matters for Kubernetes & Automation

By the end, you’ll be able to:
- Understand what yum/apt/dnf are doing under your automation tools
- Avoid “works on my machine” package issues in CI/CD
- Debug broken Kubernetes nodes at the Linux layer
- Treat package management as a continuous DevOps responsibility

This video is part of my “Linux for DevOps: From Zero to Hired” series, designed for:
- DevOps engineers
- SREs and Platform engineers
- Developers moving into Kubernetes and cloud-native roles

Next step after package management: learn Linux networking basics, so Kubernetes networking finally makes sense.

If this helped, subscribe for more Linux for DevOps content and Kubernetes-focused breakdowns.

videoTitle: Day 29: Monitoring & Logging in Azure DevOps | 30 Days Azure DevOps Challenge 🚀
videoDescription:
👋 Welcome to Day 29 of my 30 Days Azure DevOps Challenge 🚀

Today’s focus: Monitoring & Logging in Azure DevOps 🔍

Monitoring and logging are the backbone of observability in DevOps. While automation ensures smooth deployments, monitoring ensures that systems stay healthy, and logging helps you catch errors before they become big problems.

🔹 What we covered today:

Why monitoring & logging are critical in DevOps

Difference between Monitoring (health & performance) and Logging (detailed events & errors)

Using Azure DevOps pipeline logs to debug failures

Dashboards & reports for performance tracking

Integration with Azure Monitor and Application Insights for full observability

✨ Key takeaway:
Automation doesn’t stop at deployment — it continues with monitoring, logging, and observability for reliable DevOps.

📌 Next in Day 30 → Security & Compliance in Azure DevOps 🔒🚀

videoTitle: Linux Networking Tools for DevOps: curl, wget, dig & traceroute Explained with Real Demos
videoDescription:
Linux Networking Tools for DevOps: curl, wget, dig & traceroute Explained with Real Demos

In the last video, we looked at how Linux networking works internally.
In this video, we’re going fully practical: the exact tools DevOps engineers use during real production incidents.

You won’t just “learn commands,” you’ll learn what question each tool answers:
• curl – is the service actually responding?
• wget – can I download content / check connectivity quickly?
• dig – does this DNS name resolve to an IP address?
• traceroute – where does the network path break?

By the end, you’ll have a simple 4-step flow you can run every time something is “just not working” in production.

▬▬▬▬▬▬▬ Timestamps  ▬▬▬▬▬▬▬
00:00 - Why Debugging Matters More Than Networking Theory
00:37 - curl: Is the Service Actually Responding?
02:34 - wget: Download & Connectivity Check
03:24 - curl vs wget: Which One Should You Use?
03:50 - dig: Does DNS Resolve or Not?
04:34 - traceroute: Where Does Traffic Stop?
05:53 - Real Debugging Flow + What’s Next

What you’ll learn:
• How to use curl to validate services, ports, and status codes
• When wget is better than curl in CI/CD and scripts
• How dig helps you separate DNS problems from app problems
• How traceroute reveals where packets stop on the network path
• A practical, repeatable debug order for real incidents

videoTitle: Automating Azure DevOps (ADO) to SharePoint with Power Automate: Data Shuttle, Smartsheet & ADO Link
videoDescription: This video demonstrates a powerful Power Automate connector designed to integrate with Azure DevOps (ADO). Learn how to automate the process of pulling work items from ADO, generating a CSV file, and placing it into a SharePoint folder for Data Shuttle to process. The workflow includes archiving old files and ensuring only the latest data is available. See a live test showcasing how updates, like "Brooke test take two" and "Yuriy test one," are reflected in the new CSV, complete with direct URL links to specific ADO work items. We also explore future possibilities, including potentially replacing the existing Software connector, pushing data directly to Smartsheet with hyperlinks and hierarchy, and achieving bidirectional integration.

videoTitle: The DevOps Trap Nobody Talks About #shorts
videoDescription:
Most DevOps engineers get noticed only when things break. That work matters — but it rarely gets rewarded.

The real career advantage comes from preventing problems before anyone sees them. Quiet prevention beats loud firefighting.

How to move from Junior to Senior DevOps Thinking:

Master Infrastructure Stability over simple uptime.

Focus on Risk Management and automation.

Build for SRE (Site Reliability Engineering) standards.

#DevOps #CloudEngineering #SRE #EngineeringCareers #TechLeadership #SoftwareEngineering #SystemAxis #SeniorDevOps
channelDescription:
Stop building demos. Master production. Deep insights. Zero fluff. (Accent included at no extra charge.)

SystemAxis deep dives into how modern AI infrastructure, Cloud, and DevOps systems work in the real world. We move past the lab environment to explore how systems behave under load, why they fail, and how to manage the real-world costs of Platform Engineering and LLMOps.

What we cover:

    AI in Production: Scalable inference, GPU orchestration, and reliability.
    Cloud & DevOps: Linux internals, automation, and infrastructure as code.
    Platform Engineering: Building resilient, cost-aware systems.

videoTitle: SRE, DevOps, DevSecOps, Cloud Engineering, and Platform Engineering - What's the difference???
videoDescription:
The key differences between SRE, DevOps, DevSecOps, Cloud Engineering, and Platform Engineering are explained in this comprehensive video! Are you confused about these popular tech roles and methodologies? We break down each concept, explaining its core principles, responsibilities, and how they relate to one another.

In this video, you'll learn:

* **Site Reliability Engineering (SRE):** Focus on reliability, performance, and efficiency of production systems using software engineering principles.
* **DevOps:** A culture and set of practices that aims to break down silos between Development and Operations teams, fostering collaboration and automation.
* **DevSecOps:** Integrating security practices into every stage of the DevOps lifecycle, making security a shared responsibility.
* **Cloud Engineering:** Designing, building, and managing infrastructure and applications on cloud platforms like AWS, Azure, and GCP.
* **Platform Engineering:** Building and maintaining internal developer platforms to streamline software delivery and enhance developer experience.

Whether you're a student, a tech professional looking to specialise, or simply curious about these in-demand fields, this video provides a clear and concise explanation to help you understand the nuances and overlaps between SRE, DevOps, DevSecOps, Cloud Engineering, and Platform Engineering.

Don't forget to like, comment, and subscribe for more tech explainers!

videoTitle: Real world DevOps project from start to finish - Introduction
videoDescription:
CHECK OUT MY DEVOPS COURSE WITH 85% OFF COUPON AT https://sre.rs

Hello everyone,


I've made a DevOps course covering a lot of different technologies and applications,
aimed at startups, small companies and individuals who want to self-host
their infrastructure.

TL;DR:
Course page: https://www.udemy.com/course/real-world-devops-project-from-start-to-finish/?referralCode=9AC467077593D22878A2
Discount coupon is available at https://sre.rs

Details:
To get this out of the way - this course doesn't cover Kubernetes or similar -
I'm of the opinion that for startups, small companies, and especially individuals,
you probably don't need Kubernetes. Unless you have a whole DevOps team,
it usually brings more problems than benefits, and unnecessary infrastructure bills
buried a lot of startups before they got anywhere.

As for prerequisites, you can't be a complete beginner in the world of computers.
If you've never even heard of Docker, if you don't know at least something about DNS,
or if you don't have any experience with Linux, this course is probably not for you.
That being said, I do explain the basics too, but probably not in enough detail
for a complete beginner.

I encourage you to watch "free preview" videos to get the sense of what
will be covered, but here's the gist:

The goal of the course is to create an easily deployable and reproducible server
which will have "everything" a startup or a small company will need - VPN, mail, Git,
CI/CD, messaging, hosting websites and services, sharing files, calendar, etc.
It can also be useful to individuals who want to self-host all of those - I ditched Google 99.9%
and other than that being a good feeling, I'm not worried that some AI bug will lock my account
with no one to talk to about resolving the issue.

Considering that it covers a wide variety of topics, it doesn't go in depth in any of those.
Think of it as going down a highway towards the end destination, but on the way there I show you
all the junctions where I think it's useful to do more research on the subject.

We'll deploy services inside Docker and LXC (Linux Containers). Those will include
a mail server (iRedMail), Zulip (Slack and Microsoft Teams alternative), GitLab (with GitLab Runner and CI/CD),
Nextcloud (file sharing, calendar, contacts, etc.), checkmk (monitoring solution), Pi-hole (ad blocking on DNS level),
Traefik with Docker and file providers (a single HTTP/S entry point with automatic routing and TLS certificates).

We'll set up WireGuard, a modern and fast VPN solution for secure access to VPS' internal network,
and I'll also show you how to get a wildcard TLS certificate with certbot and DNS provider.

To wrap it all up, we'll write a simple Python application that will compare a list of the desired backups
with the list of finished backups, and send a result to a Zulip stream.
We'll write the application, do a 'git push' to GitLab which will trigger a CI/CD pipeline
that will build a Docker image, push it to a private registry, and then,
with the help of the GitLab runner, run it on the VPS and post a result to a Zulip stream with a webhook.


If you apply the coupon, I'd appreciate if you leave your feedback on Udemy
after you're done and spread the word about the course. It would mean a lot.


I hope that you find it useful.


Happy learning,
Predrag

videoTitle: Space Domain Awareness: DevOps and Software Integration Shaping the Future of Military Operations

Gagnon invites Bryon Kroger, Rise8 CEO and former Kessel Run co-founder to share his invaluable insights on Space Domain Awareness. [0:00] Introduction by Maj. Gen. Gregory J. Gagnon

[2:16] Kessel Run's contribution to the warfighter and the significance of continuous delivery
[3:00] The importance of learning from deployments and the current limitations of IT infrastructure in the defense sector
[3:52] Insights into the acquisition process, continuous delivery, and the need for feedback from warfighters
[5:27] Challenges of enterprise IT solutions in production and the negative impact of mandated solutions

videoTitle: Cold Starts Explained: The Hidden Challenge of Serverless Computing #serverlesscomputing #devops
videoDescription:
In a serverless environment, functions run on-demand as a response to a triggered event, like a user request. Since the initialization of a function instance takes some time, this approach causes what we call startup latency and “cold starts.”

The startup latency can vary significantly — it may range from a few milliseconds to several seconds and it depends on different factors — many of them under the developer’s control.

videoTitle: DevOps vs SRE Explained | What's the difference?
videoDescription:
In this video, I break down the key differences between DevOps and Site Reliability Engineering (SRE), two essential approaches to modern infrastructure management. While both aim to improve software delivery and system reliability, their goals, methods, and roles are distinct.

Key Takeaways:
- DevOps: Focuses on collaboration between development and operations teams to enhance speed, automation, and deployment efficiency.
- SRE: Prioritizes system reliability, performance, and accountability through software engineering principles and metrics like SLOs and error budgets.
- Real-World Applications: How these concepts are applied in various organizations, and how DevOps and SRE can complement each other.

#itcareer #realtech #technology #devops #devopslife #devopsculture #devopsengineer #sre #sitereliabilityengineering

videoTitle: Evig Eies | DNA-DevOps | The Song of the Infinite Cycle of Digital Creation and Evolution
videoDescription:
Welcome to the sonic universe of "Evig Eies", the track that dives into the poetic intersection of code, creation, and human nature.

Inspired by the concept of DNA-DevOps—the fundamental, organic rhythm that pulses beneath all software engineering and innovation—this song is a reflection on the Infinite Cycle of Creation, Refinement, and Lasting Ownership.

🌌 The Essence of the Music:
"Evig Eies" (which translates to "Forever/Eternally Owned" or "Eternal Property") is our declaration that the knowledge, the code, and the bridges we build digitally are inseparable parts of who we are.

The track moves from a sparse and reflective start (Piano and Cello) to a subtly driving rhythm (Bass and Drums), mirroring a project's journey: from the "Concept's spark" to a "Living stream".

It’s an homage to the "Silent promise" present in every line of code and the relentless pursuit to refine, adapt, and "conquer fear" in the tech environment.

🎼 Who is this song for?
For software engineers, developers, IT professionals, digital artists, and anyone who finds beauty and purpose in the cycle of continuous creation and improvement. It's the soundtrack for late-night coding sessions, for learning, and for the union between logic and emotion.

Leave a comment and tell us which part of the lyrics resonated most with you! Do you feel this DNA-DevOps in your daily routine?

(Evig Eies, forever owned, forever known...)

Verse 1:
(Piano and Cello begin, sparse and reflective)
Lines of code, a digital thread,
Weaving futures, words unsaid.
From concept's spark to a living stream,
A silent promise, a waking dream.
Chorus:
(Bass and drums enter, subtle and driving, clean electric guitar adds texture)
Oh, DNA-DevOps, a rhythm deep inside,
Where logic flows and errors hide.
Evig Eies, a truth we hold so dear,
Building bridges, conquering fear.
Verse 2:
(Vocals become more prominent, velvety and slightly melancholic)
Through countless iterations, we refine,
Each commit, a purpose, a design.
From whispered thoughts to a grand display,
Guiding progress, lighting the way.
Chorus:
(Instrumentation builds slightly, still restrained)
Oh, DNA-DevOps, a rhythm deep inside,
Where logic flows and errors hide.
Evig Eies, a truth we hold so dear,
Building bridges, conquering fear.
Bridge:
(Cello takes a more melodic lead, piano arpeggios, drums become more intricate)
In the quiet hum of the server's grace,
A human touch in this digital space.
We learn, we grow, we adapt, we mend,
A cycle endless, without an end.
Chorus:
(Fuller sound, but still maintaining the minimalist feel)
Oh, DNA-DevOps, a rhythm deep inside,
Where logic flows and errors hide.
Evig Eies, a truth we hold so dear,
Building bridges, conquering fear.
Outro:
(Instrumentation slowly fades, piano and cello linger)
Evig Eies, forever owned, forever known...
A silent promise, deeply sown.
(Silence)

videoTitle: Power BI  for Business Users - WK15 - SVG's, UDF's and DevOps... Happy New Year!
videoDescription:
We ended up adding a few SVG's to our Jesmond Dene 2025 summary, so lets walk through how you do that and how you place your SVG's (Scalable Vector Graphics) and how you can industrialise their usage by creating a UDF (User Defined Function), while UDF's are still in preview they are a significant addition to the platform and they are here to stay. 

DevOps in Power BI is something many companies are keen to utilise, and to do so, you need to consider your environment's layout. We recommend splitting ETL and Modelling steps largely so you can manage those scripts separately. When everything is placed in a single master PBIX file or Project, it becomes nearly impossible to manage and govern. 

We touch on governance in this video, but we do not go into detail. Ultimately, the application of your governance layers within your Power BI or Fabric environment must align with your corporate model. We do have recommendations, and we have seen success and failure in multiple organisations. This is not just about putting rules in place; really, the governance of Power BI has to fit your organisation to be successful. 

We absolutely love Kerry Kolosko's site and if you are looking to start with SVG's she has a fantastic library to help you get started. 
https://kerrykolosko.com/

As we approach the end of this series, we invite you to comment below on what you would like us to do next. Should we aim for another series like this? Are there elements we have not covered in enough detail? Should I keep using the Business User account for all our videos? Let us know!

videoTitle: GET EXAM JUNIPER AUTOMATION AND DEVOPS, ASSOCIATE (JNCIA-DEVOPS) - CODE JN0-224 - JANUARY 07, 2026
videoDescription:
This self-paced course provides students with foundational knowledge required to automate Junos using NetDevOps automation tools, protocols, and technologies. 
Students receive hands-on experience with tools and languages relevant to automating the Junos OS platform in a NetDevOps environment. 
The course includes an introduction to the basic NetDevOps practices, Junos APIs, and Network Configuration Protocol (NETCONF). 
It also focuses on using Python, Junos PyEZ, Representational State Transfer (REST) API methods, and the Junos REST API to automate Junos. 
This course introduces XML, JavaScript Object Notation (JSON), and YAML, as these languages facilitate Junos automation. 
This course also introduces Juniper platform automation using REST API. 
Through demonstrations and hands-on labs, students will gain experience with automating the Junos operating system. 
This course uses Junos OS Release 24.2R1, Junos PyEZ 2.6.3, and Python 3.8.10.

videoTitle: SysAdmin Weekly - 011 - How is Agentic AI Changing DevOps?
videoDescription:
This week on SysAdmin Weekly, Andy is joined by Luke Orellana, a fellow IT war buddy from the MSP trenches who's now a Senior Engineering Manager at Microsoft (yes, that Microsoft) working with AI Agents on a daily basis!

In this episode we unpack the good, the bad, and the "seriously, who thought YAML was a good idea"? parts of Infra-as-Code from Terraform and Pulumi to PowerShell DSC and Packer pipelines. Luke drops wisdom on platform engineering, the rise of AI agents with their impact on DevOps, and how he rewrote entire Terraform libraries because apparently, sleep is optional.

Also in this episode:

- Why password resets are a scam (Forrester says $70 a pop — no thanks).
- The glorious chaos of auditors asking for 30-day resets in 2025 (because security theater must go on).
- Andy’s obsession with Linux Mint Debian Edition and the Tux shrine on his desk.
- The legendary Domino’s Pizza Terraform provider. Yes. That’s real.
 
We also answer critical questions like:

- Can an AI agent wreck your entire Git repo?
- Should sysadmins fear change or just automate it?
- And what’s more powerful: Terraform CDK or the sheer willpower of a sysadmin trying to avoid YAML?

Grab your favorite caffeine source, commit to main (regrets optional), and get ready to laugh, learn, and question your life choices. This one’s got code, chaos, and caffeine-fueled commentary.

Episode Resources Below!

videoTitle: Day 23 – Docker with Azure Pipelines | Azure DevOps 30 Days Challenge
videoDescription:
Welcome to Day 23 of my 30 Days Azure DevOps Challenge 🚀

Today’s focus: Docker with Azure Pipelines

🔹 What is Docker?
Think of Docker as a box that contains everything your app needs – code, dependencies, and environment – so it runs the same anywhere.

🔹 What is Azure Pipelines?
Azure Pipelines is the delivery system that builds that box, tests it, and ships it to where it needs to run.

Together, Docker + Azure Pipelines solve the famous “it works on my machine” problem and make deployments fast, reliable, and consistent across environments.

👉 Key takeaway:

Docker = the box for your app 🐳

Azure Pipelines = the delivery system for that box 🚚

📌 Next in Day 24 → we’ll connect Docker with Kubernetes to see how containers run at scale.

✅ Watch the full 30 Days of Azure DevOps Playlist here: [paste playlist link]

videoTitle: Continuous Delivery is just 10% about automation ... #devops #development #webdevelopment
videoDescription:
Continuous Delivery is just 10% about tools ...


And 90% about how we work, the relationships, and our practices as a team and company.

That was a core topic of our one-hour-long discussion about "What is Continuous Delivery" I had with Bryan Finster.

We met because of the misconceptions we see out there.

𝗪𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗜 𝘀𝗲𝗲 𝗾𝘂𝗶𝘁𝗲 𝗼𝗳𝘁𝗲𝗻:
• CD is the automation part of CI/CD
• Automation (CD) isn't the silver bullet 


𝗢𝘁𝗵𝗲𝗿 𝗺𝗶𝘀𝗰𝗼𝗻𝗰𝗲𝗽𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀 𝘄𝗲 𝗵𝗮𝘃𝗲 𝗰𝗼𝘃𝗲𝗿𝗲𝗱:
• Staging environments are the final place for testing in Continuous Delivery.
• Open-source development is compatible with Continuous Delivery.
• Complicated pipelines and numerous testing tools are necessary.
• Developers should stay isolated and avoid business discussions.
• You need separate testing tools and teams for every type of test.
• Continuous Delivery requires an already high-performing team.
• Deployments should only happen when a feature is fully ready.
• Developers are not capable of testing their own code.
• Continuous Delivery only works for tech companies.
• Engineers should focus on code over outcomes.
• Deploying on Fridays is inherently risky.
• Code freezes improve stability. 😃


𝗪𝗮𝗻𝘁 𝘁𝗼 𝗹𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗻 𝘁𝗼 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗳𝘂𝗹𝗹 𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻?
Click on my profile for the YouTube, Spotify, and Blog versions.


What's your experience?


Have a great Sunday,
Adrian

videoTitle: Azure DevOps & SpiraTeam: Boost Productivity & Quality - Complete Tutorial & Walkthrough
videoDescription:
This comprehensive tutorial and walkthrough demonstrates how to seamlessly integrate Microsoft Azure DevOps with Inflectra Spira (SpiraTest, SpiraTeam, or SpiraPlan). Discover how this powerful integration boosts productivity and streamlines your entire software development lifecycle (SDLC). ⭐️

Key Moments:

• 0:01:14 Introduction to Work Item Synchronization & Creating User Stories
• 0:03:09 Integrating Source Code & CI/CD Pipelines
• 0:06:21 Creating & Executing Test Cases in Spira
• 0:09:03 Logging and Synchronizing Defects (Spira to Azure DevOps)
• 0:11:18 Automated Test Results via Azure Pipelines in Spira
• 0:13:43 Bidirectional Defect Updates & Collaboration

We'll guide you through the process of setting up and utilizing this integration, highlighting bidirectional synchronization for key work items:

• Requirements/User Stories: Learn how user stories flow from Azure DevOps into Spira.
• Tasks: See how tasks are synchronized for efficient project management.
• Incidents/Defects: Understand the full lifecycle of defects, from logging in Spira to appearing in Azure DevOps, complete with detailed test results and comments.

The video also covers integrating your source code repositories (like Azure Repos) and CI/CD pipelines (e.g., Azure Pipelines) to provide full traceability from code commits and automated test results directly within Spira. We'll show you how automated tests (using frameworks like JUnit, NUnit, Selenium, Playwright) can automatically update test statuses in Spira.

Benefits of this Integration:

• Enhanced Traceability: Link requirements, test cases, defects, and source code for a complete picture 🔗.
• Improved Collaboration: Enable development teams in Azure DevOps and QA/BA teams in Spira to work hand-in-glove 🤝.
• Streamlined Workflows: Automate the flow of critical information, reducing manual effort and errors ⚙️.
• Faster Feedback Loops: Get immediate updates on defect status and test results across platforms ⚡.

Whether you're looking to achieve seamless development, optimize your testing process, or simply boost overall team productivity, this tutorial provides a complete walkthrough of integrating Azure DevOps and Spira.

videoTitle: New 📚 Release! Architecting and Implementing DevOps for Infrastructure Management in Azure #books
videoDescription:
New 📚 Release! Architecting and Implementing DevOps for Infrastructure Management in Azure: Infrastructure DevOps in Azure: Configure, Deploy, & Automate Your Azure resources with terraform, GitHub Actions and Ansible by Ashish Raj

Embark on a transformative journey from basic to intricate infrastructure configurations—think high availability, scalability, and security—all through the power of Infrastructure as Code. Dive into the automation of Azure resource deployments, leveraging DevOps tools with comprehensive, step-by-step guidance and practical examples. But the learning doesn't stop at deployment; delve deeper into automated governance and monitoring, ensuring your infrastructure is not just built but also managed with precision and efficiency.

Find it on Leanpub!

#MicrosoftAzure #coding #programming #newreleases #books #bookstan

Link: https://leanpub.com/devopsinazure

About the Book

In the face of accelerated development cycles, Infrastructure teams must align with the culture of rapid deployment and infrastructure versioning. Embracing Infrastructure as Code, Continuous Integration, and Configuration Management practices becomes imperative. Tools like Terraform, GitHub Actions, and Ansible empower infrastructure engineers to implement scalable Infrastructure as Code practices in Azure.

This book serves as a thorough guide for deploying, configuring, and automating Azure infrastructure using DevOps tools. It navigates through cloud architecture patterns with DevOps tools, illustrating their application in Azure solution design. Subsequently, the book delves into the implementation of the architected solution, utilizing DevOps tools like Terraform, GitHub Actions, Packer, Ansible, etc., to address specific architectural requirements with emphasis on scaling the solution architecture and establishing governance, aligning with DevOps principles.

Upon finishing this book, readers will be equipped with the expertise to transform business requirements into Azure-compatible solution architectures, seamlessly incorporating a DevOps approach to deployment. Readers will demonstrate proficiency in executing end-to-end deployment with governance and monitoring proficiently through the consistent application of DevOps tools.

About the Author

Ashish Raj is a technologist and storyteller who helps engineering teams improve their velocity. He believes the biggest challenges facing engineers aren't technical, but not knowing how to tie people, process and technology. With an extensive background spanning innovative startups to leading tech conglomerates, Ashish currently serves as a Cloud & DevOps Architect at Haufe Group.

A fervent advocate and contributor to the DevOps and cloud communities, he shares expertise through webinars and local meetups. Holding Microsoft certifications in DevOps, Architecture, and Certified Microsoft Trainer. Ashish co-founded "AzureTalk," a prominent IM-based global Azure community on Telegram, and initiated "AzureDevOpsPro," a thriving DevOps community. He shares educational cloud and DevOps videos on his YouTube channel, youtube.com/ashishrajsrivastava

videoTitle: DevOps Hands-On | Ansible – Day 4  ( DevOpsFarm Day 46 )
videoDescription:
In this in-depth session, we dive into the critical world of DevOps monitoring and master the industry-leading open-source tools: Grafana, Prometheus, and Loki.

Learn why monitoring is essential for getting system feedback, taking proactive action, and preventing system failure due to issues like high CPU usage, low RAM, or disk space depletion. We cover the key aspects you must monitor, including system resources, logs, and traces.




What you will learn in this session:


The Importance of Monitoring: Understand the benefits, including anomaly detection, generating alerts, and creating useful dashboards for historical data analysis.



Core Monitoring Tools: An overview of popular tools like Grafana, New Relic, Datadog, and Dynatrace.



Prometheus Explained: A deep dive into Prometheus, the time-series database used for collecting and tracking metrics (like CPU usage over time).



Loki for Logging: Learn how Loki is used for log collection and parsing, making logs consumable by Grafana.



The Grafana Stack in Action: See how Grafana serves as the visualization layer, consuming data from Prometheus and Loki to create powerful dashboards and configure alerts.



Practical Demo: We demonstrate connecting data sources, exploring metrics using PromQL, and setting up label-based notification policies to ensure the right teams are alerted instantly.


Whether you are a beginner or a seasoned DevOps professional, this guide provides the knowledge and practical steps needed to implement robust monitoring for any application or microservice environment.

videoTitle: Master DevOps with PROMETHEUS Easily
videoDescription:
Are you new to DevOps and wondering what Prometheus actually does? In this short video, we break it down in a simple, beginner-friendly way.

Prometheus is a powerful open-source monitoring tool used by DevOps teams around the world. It pulls metrics from your servers, stores them as time-series data, and triggers alerts whenever thresholds are broken. This proactive approach helps teams detect issues before they impact users, improving uptime and system reliability.

Unlike log-based monitoring, Prometheus focuses on quantitative metrics like CPU usage, memory consumption, response times, and error rates. By monitoring these metrics continuously, DevOps engineers and SREs (Site Reliability Engineers) can maintain healthy systems, reduce downtime, and scale cloud-native infrastructure efficiently.

This video is perfect for beginners who want to understand Prometheus in under 20 seconds and start applying monitoring in real-world projects. Whether you’re managing corporate training platforms, retail applications, or cloud infrastructure, this knowledge is essential.

💡 Save this video and follow the channel for more quick DevOps tutorials, beginner tips, and monitoring hacks. Stay ahead in your career and make complex DevOps tools simple!

videoTitle: DevOps Hands-On | Ansible – Day 1 ( DevOpsFarm Day 43 )
videoDescription:
Welcome to Day 1  of Anisble in the DevOps Full Course by DevOpsFarm! 🚀

This video transcript details a deep-dive tutorial on Ansible, the industry-leading Configuration as Code (CAC) tool.

Here is a complete YouTube package, including the video description, chapters, and tags.

YouTube Video Description
This is your complete, hands-on tutorial for Ansible, the powerful, agentless tool for Configuration as Code (CAC). We will show you how Ansible solves the major DevOps problem of managing and configuring hundreds of servers efficiently and consistently.

We begin by establishing the crucial difference between Infrastructure as Code (IaC) tools like Terraform (which creates machines) and Configuration as Code tools like Ansible (which configures those machines).

What you will learn in this video:

➤ Configuration Management Fundamentals: Understand why manual scripting on multiple machines is inefficient and how Ansible automates security hardening, software installation (like PostgreSQL, Grafana), and application deployment.

➤ Ansible Architecture: Learn about the Controller Node and why Ansible is agentless, using standard SSH/SCP protocols to manage hosts, unlike other tools that require an agent installation.

➤ Core Concepts Explained: Deep dive into the four essential elements of Ansible:

➤ Modules: The basic units of work (Python scripts) that perform specific tasks (e.g., ping, shell, mysql).

➤ Playbooks: YAML files that define a set of tasks to run on specific hosts.

➤ Inventory: The list of hosts (IPs, usernames) that Ansible manages.

➤ Idempotence: A key concept ensuring that running the same command multiple times yields the same, predictable outcome, preventing configuration drift.

➤ Terraform vs. Ansible: A clear comparison, including why Terraform is better suited for Cloud (like AWS) and configuration management tools are essential for On-Premise (data center) environments.

Chapters :-

videoTitle: How to explain Grafana and Prometheus Stack deployment in Production in DevOps SRE interviews?
videoDescription:
Support my work: https://buymeacoffee.com/techapricate

In this video, I explain how to confidently describe the Grafana + Prometheus observability and monitoring stack deployment in production during DevOps and SRE interviews.

You’ll learn how Terraform modules stored in GitLab can be used to deploy the kube-prometheus-stack Helm chart for a complete Observability setup. I’ll walk you through how Prometheus collects application and cluster-level metrics from AWS EKS clusters, integrates with Prometheus Mimir for long-term storage, and how Grafana is configured with Mimir as a data source and PostgreSQL as a backend database.

This explanation will help you stand out in interviews by showing practical knowledge of real-world production-grade observability setups, from infrastructure as code (IaC) to monitoring architecture design.

🧠 What You’ll Learn:
How to explain Prometheus and Grafana observability architecture in interviews
How to use Terraform + GitLab for deploying kube-prometheus-stack
Integration of Prometheus with Mimir for scalable metric storage
How Grafana connects to Mimir as a data source and uses a PostgreSQL backend
How metrics are collected from EKS clusters and workloads via Kubernetes APIs

Best practices to explain Monitoring, Alerting, and Visualization in production

🚀 Technologies Covered:
Terraform | GitLab CI/CD | Prometheus | Grafana | Prometheus Mimir | PostgreSQL | kube-prometheus-stack | Helm | AWS EKS | Kubernetes Observability | Cloud Monitoring

videoTitle: The Fastest Way to Manage Docker Containers (Real DevOps Walkthrough)
videoDescription:
Learn how to manage Docker containers like a real DevOps engineer or System Admin.
In this hands-on tutorial, we will create, run, stop, restart, delete, inspect, and monitor Docker containers, including Ubuntu and Nginx, while tracking CPU, RAM, and network usage in real time.

Whether you're preparing for DevOps, System Admin, Cloud, or Site Reliability Engineering — this video is all you need.

🕒 Timestamps
Time Content
00:00 Hook — Manage Docker like a DevOps expert
00:10 What you will learn
00:24 Intro — Phuong here 👋
00:50 Check existing Docker images
01:16 Pull Ubuntu image (if missing)
02:05 Run Ubuntu container (with port mapping)
03:22 Stop container
04:00 Restart container
05:05 Delete container
07:10 Run NGINX container
08:41 Inspect container details
09:18 View container status
10:26 View container logs
10:57 Monitor CPU / RAM / Network / IO (docker stats)
12:16 Remove a Docker image
12:32 Final recap & CTA
✅ Copy/Paste Commands Used in This Video

Check existing images:

docker image ls

Download image if missing:
sudo docker pull ubuntu:latest

Run Ubuntu container (detached + port mapping):
docker run -it -d -p 8080:80 --name my-ubuntu-container ubuntu:latest

Check running container:
docker container ls

Stop container:
docker container stop my-ubuntu-container

Restart container:
docker container start my-ubuntu-container

Delete container:
docker container rm my-ubuntu-container

Run NGINX container:
docker run -d --name nginx_container -p 8080:80 nginx:latest

Inspect container:
docker inspect nginx_container

Show only container status:
docker inspect --format='{{.State.Status}}' nginx_container

View logs (debugging):
docker logs nginx_container

Monitor resource usage (all containers):
docker stats

Monitor specific container:
docker stats nginx_container

Remove image:
docker image rm nginx_app

Welcome to Day 6 of our Linux for DevOps training series by DevOpsFarm IT Solutions. In this session, we dive into the fundamentals of networking — crucial knowledge for every DevOps, SRE, or Cloud Engineer.

✅ Public vs private IP ranges (Class A, B, C)

ping google.com                # Test network reachability  
nslookup devopsfarm.in         # Query DNS records

ip a                           # Show IP address of interfaces

videoTitle: The Truth About AI Job Replacement: DevOps, Coding & White-Collar Work | Performant Professional
videoDescription:
"If you're not replacing 20% of your staff with AI, you're doing it wrong." That's the battle cry from Silicon Valley right now. But is it true? And what happens to the rest of us?
In this episode, Michael Forrester, Chris McNabb, and Louis Puster dive deep into AI's real impact on the tech job market. We're not here to hype or doom—we're here to talk about what's actually happening on the ground in July 2025.
From Claude Code deleting entire Kubernetes clusters to chatbots that can't connect you to a human, we share our real experiences with AI tools and examine whether the productivity gains are worth the chaos being injected into organizations.
Key discussion points:

77,000 tech positions eliminated in 2025 due to AI automation
Why AI replaced creative jobs first (not engineering jobs)
The probabilistic problem: AI that ignores its own guardrails
Junior developers vs senior developers: who benefits more from AI?
The career ladder crisis: if entry-level jobs disappear, where do seniors come from?
Support chatbots that never let you talk to a human (looking at you, AT&T)
Adam Smith, capitalism, and why "a market without morals consumes itself"
How to adapt: you can't refuse the next evolution

📣 We want to hear from you:
→ How is AI affecting your job right now?
→ Are you seeing productivity gains or just more chaos?
Drop your thoughts in the comments—we read every one.
—————————————————

videoTitle: DevOps Hands-On | Ansible – Day 2  ( DevOpsFarm Day 44 )
videoDescription:
Welcome to Day 2  of Anisble in the DevOps Full Course by DevOpsFarm! 🚀
This is the continuation of our comprehensive tutorial on Ansible, the powerful, agentless Configuration as Code (CAC) tool. In this session, we dive directly into the hands-on practice, demonstrating how to set up an environment and execute configuration tasks across multiple Linux machines.

We begin by establishing the crucial difference between Infrastructure as Code (IaC) tools like Terraform and Configuration as Code tools like Ansible. You will then be guided through provisioning the necessary AWS infrastructure using Terraform, establishing the Controller Node, and connecting it to the Managed Nodes.

What you will learn in this session:
➤ Ansible Architecture: Reviewing the Controller Node and Managed Node design, and the vital role of Python on the Controller.

➤ Lab Setup: Provisioning three EC2 instances on AWS using Terraform to prepare for the demo.

➤ Running Commands: Understanding the two primary ways to run Ansible: Ad-Hoc Commands (for quick, one-shot testing and debugging) and Playbooks. 

➤ Ansible Modules: Deep dive into how modules (like apt or yum) are used for specific tasks, and how to control them with parameters (e.g., present or absent).

➤ Mastering Inventory: A detailed breakdown of the hosts.ini file, including defining host addresses, setting connection variables (ansible_user, ansible_password), and logically organizing machines using Inventory Groups (e.g., front-end and back-end).

➤ Best Practices: How to use the [all:vars] section in your inventory to apply common configurations globally, adhering to the DRY (Don't Repeat Yourself) principle.

➤ Advanced Topics: Introduction to Ansible Variables, Jinja2 Templating, and the concept of Ansible Roles for highly reusable, community-driven configurations (like installing PostgreSQL).

videoTitle: Learn DevOps for beginners – start like this!
videoDescription:
You’ve probably heard “DevOps” thrown around like it’s some secret tech club, right?

Truth is — if you can use a computer, you can learn DevOps.

In this short, I’ll show you exactly how to start the right way:

Step 1: Learn Git & GitHub — where all DevOps teamwork happens
Step 2: Understand basic Linux commands
Step 3: Try Docker to containerize apps
Step 4: Use GitHub Actions for simple CI/CD automation

Don’t overcomplicate it — just start with these four, and you’ll understand 90% of modern DevOps workflows.

Subscribe for more beginner-friendly DevOps and tech breakdowns.

videoTitle: DevOps Interview: IAM, Permissions & Lockouts
videoDescription:
This simulated DevOps interview focuses on IAM design, permission failures, cross account access, lockout scenarios, and decision making under pressure. It explores real world trade offs between security, speed, and operational stability.

Ideal for DevOps, Cloud, SRE, and Platform engineers preparing for AWS or multi account architecture interviews.

Pause the video, answer each question out loud, and compare your reasoning with strong sample responses.
channelDescription: Breaking down infra in relatable words.

videoTitle: DevOps Interview: Security vs Speed
videoDescription:
This simulated DevOps interview explores one of the toughest real world tradeoffs: security versus speed. You’ll face realistic scenarios involving zero day vulnerabilities, risky production launches, audit findings, pressure from sales, and balancing delivery velocity with long term platform integrity. The focus is not just technical knowledge, but judgment, communication, and risk management under uncertainty.

Ideal for DevOps, Cloud, SRE, and Platform engineers preparing for mid to senior level interviews.

Pause the video after each question. Answer out loud. Then compare your reasoning with strong, structured sample responses. Train how you think, not just what you know.
